Yes, open-source GIS tools can be used to create a comprehensive situational awareness system during natural disasters. Some popular open-source GIS tools are QGIS, GRASS GIS, and GeoServer.

These tools can be used to create maps and visualizations that display information such as the location and severity of the disaster, the distribution of affected populations, and the location of relief resources. They can also be used to track the progress of relief efforts and to identify areas that still require assistance.

Here's an example code snippet using Python and the QGIS library to load a shapefile of disaster-affected areas and display it on a map:
```python
import os
from qgis.core import *
from qgis.gui import *
from PyQt5.QtGui import *
from PyQt5.QtCore import *

# Set up QGIS application
app = QgsApplication([], False)
QgsApplication.setPrefixPath("C:/OSGeo4W64/apps/qgis", True)
QgsApplication.initQgis()

# Load shapefile
shp_path = "path/to/affected/areas.shp"
layer_name = "Affected Areas"
layer = QgsVectorLayer(shp_path, layer_name, "ogr")

# Add layer to map
QgsProject.instance().addMapLayer(layer)

# Set up map canvas
canvas = QgsMapCanvas()
canvas.setExtent(layer.extent())
canvas.setLayers([layer])

# Show map
canvas.show()
```
This code will load a shapefile of disaster-affected areas and display it on a map using the QGIS library. Similar code can be used to display other types of data, such as relief resources or population distribution.
